episodes.summary:

[Click here to download the WDIS: Options 101 Syllabus](https://s3.amazonaws.com/tastytradepublicmedia/website/cms/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf/original/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf)

Dr. Jim brings Brittany back to the options pricing model to educate her that the OPM is everywhere! Brittany learns that we typically solve for volatility within the OPM, rather than the option's price itself, which yields an estimate of what volatility might be. Her main takeaway from today's lesson is that this estimated volatility has a systematic bias to it in that it is exaggerated.

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - March 6, 2017 - Iron Flys
episodes.summary: With our beginner series, we continue to work through a detailed description for each of the strategies that we like to utilize, and for the time being, we are sticking with the [defined-risk genre](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/rolling-defined-risk-trades-11-22-2016), which can really help control our [emotions in trading](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/prospect-theory-12-09-2016). Today, we learn the basics of an [Iron Fly](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/strategy-session-iron-fly-06-02-2016), which is effectively a short straddle with short, at-the-money (ATM) options plus two long options on either side to act as “wings”. In other words, an Iron Fly is nothing more than a combination of two vertical spreads: a short put spread and a short call spread. Kai joins the set today, and the guys get into an interesting discussion about risk, return, and delta selection in the selection of those long strikes.

episodes.title: Futures Measures - March 6, 2017 - Agricultural Market Outlook
episodes.summary:
Pete and Katie take a look at the agricultural asset class to see what potential opportunities lie ahead in Beans (/ZS), Wheat (/ZW) and Corn (/ZC). 

While this is typically a "quieter time" for Ags, planting season is just around the corner. And while recent years have seen the Ags trading at a discount due to high yields, the weather influence on these crops makes the next few months uncertain. 

Find out how the "Seasonality" of Wheat is already built into the prices and how steep contango in the product makes this crop difficult to roll forward. Plus, get Pete's take on the next WASDE report and how planting intentions could start to move these markets, ultimately presenting some tape action that Pete and Katie can take advantage of.

episodes.title: Know Your Options - March 6, 2017 - The Market's Daily Moves in 2017
episodes.summary:
Liz and Jenny invite James in the studio for yet another edition of Know Your Options "Best of the Research Team". 

James switches gears and looks at the market in a new light. The analysis focuses on January and February 2017 as they compare to the last 60 years in the market. 

###The Study

* S&P 500 Index (SPX) 
* 1950 - Present
* Analyzed Daily % changes (close to close)  
* Subdivided and averaged positive days and negative days
* Compared the average magnitude of negative days as a % of average positive magnitude.

###Results

There has been a clear drop in the magnitude of daily moves over the last few years, with January and February of 2017 seeing extremely small moves. 

Next, the team looked at magnitude of negative days relative to positive days. They found that 2017 so far has seen negative days far out paced by the magnitude of positive days. The only year where January and February matched this year was 1987. 

This doesn't mean the team expects a huge market sell off, just a reversion to higher market volatility. Hear what James, Liz & Jenny have to say! Check out the segment!

Market Measures - March 6, 2017 - Market Corrections
episodes.summary:
As premium sellers, we would like to see two sided markets as these provide us with the most opportunities. However, the S&P has gained 15% since the presidential election. It seems that the market has only drifted up with no corrections.

So today, Tom and Tony are going to put some context around this observation. They look at the number of 5% and 10% corrections in the market since 1994. You will see whether the recent market action is normal in historical perspective or not.

episodes.title: Options Jive - March 6, 2017 - How Long Until Profits?
episodes.summary:
We at tastytrade favor strategies that incorporate short options – betting on both little price movement and a decrease in [implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility). A few of our favorite strategies for most environments are the short [straddle](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle) and [strangle](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strangle) in the S&P 500 ETF (SPY) and short [call spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread) in the S&P 500 Volatility Index (VIX). Today we take a look at what percentage of these trades have historically been able to be managed at their management target:

* SPY Straddles at 25% of credit received
* SPY Strangles at 50% of credit received
* VIX Call Spreads at 50% of credit received

We found that, historically, these trades were managed for a profit, when they could be, in around half the time to expiration. Of note, the strangles were managed for 50% about 4 days earlier than the straddles could be managed for 25%. Check out the segment for more details.

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - March 3, 2017 - Weekly Portfolio Analysis
episodes.summary: It’s the end of another week, and we spend the day working through the portfolio. As we usually do, we begin with a thorough discussion of the three outstanding positions in our old portfolio: short IWM, long TLT, and long SLV. In particular, the SLV trade analysis offered us a textbook example of our mechanical approach to [consistent cost basis reduction](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/cost-basis-reduction-03-17-2016). From there, we took a look at our QQQ [Calendar Spread](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/strategy-session-calendar-spreads-04-14-2016) that hasn’t worked at all and our SPY [Poor Man’s Covered Put](https://tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/the-poor-mans-version-covered-calls-covered-puts-02-21-2017) that also has been a dud. In doing so, we’re able to see why we label our maximum loss on a Calendar as the debit paid and why the relationship between the cost basis and spread width is so important for a PMCP.

episodes.title: Market Measures - March 3, 2017 - Results Since the Election
episodes.summary:
Since the election, the S&P 500 and Russell 2000 has been up 11% and 17% respectively. With such a large movement in the Russell (IWM), how has a strategy of selling [Strangles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strangle) performed? We decided to look into it further. In the first study, the Research Team examined the results of selling 30 [delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) strangles in IWM every week. The results are shown below:
Success Rate 80%
Average Profit/Loss at Exp. $99
Largest Gain $369
Largest Loss -$1016
Average Gain $193
Average Loss -$275
A graphic showed the results of selling the strangles the day before the election to the current day. With the exception of an initial loss, the strategy has been successful. The study further drives home the importance of remaining consistent. For more information, watch the Market Measure with Tom and Tony.

episodes.title: Options Jive - March 3, 2017 - Selling Options in Bull and Bear Markets
episodes.summary:
The overall market is in either a bull or bear market depending on whether the market has trended up or down in recent price movement. Since we are primarily options sellers, we thought it would be interesting to see how our strategies have worked in these two types of market.

The three strategies that we are looking at today are:

* Short VIX [Call Spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread)
* Short SPY [Straddles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle)
* Short SPY [Iron Condors](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/iron-condor)

And we are looking at how these strategies acted in both of these environments since 2006.

###The Results
The short VIX call spreads and short SPY straddles performed very well in bull markets, but underperformed in bear markets. When we defined our risk with the SPY iron condor, the strategy was profitable in all markets. Tom advocates for having short deltas because this will help offset losses in short premium trades when a bear market does present itself.

Closing the Gap - Futures Edition - March 3, 2017 - Copper and the S&P 500
episodes.summary:
Past performance indicates that Copper (/HG) and E Mini S&P 500 Futures (/ES) often experience price turns at similar times. With /ES continuously reaching new highs and a recent rally in /HG, Pete presents a trade idea that would capitalize on a reversion in equities. Based on notional value and current implied volatility, tastytrade walks through this pairs trade setup and also presents an alternative trade that incorporates theta. Tune in for all of the details including how to manage this position and what to expect from a P/L standpoint. ###E-Mini S&P 500 Contract Specs
* Symbol: /ES
* Contract Size: 50 x Index
* Delta: 50
* Minimum Tick: 0.25
* Tick Value: $12.50
* Expiration: March, June, September, December
###COPPER Contract Specs
* Symbol: /HG
* Contract Size:25,000 lbs.
* Delta: 25000
* Minimum Tick: $0.00050
* Tick Value: $12.50
* Expiration: March, May, July, September, December

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - March 2, 2017 - Context Around Charm
episodes.summary: Last week, Frank and I made a little discovery, when we unearthed delta’s derivative with respect to time – [charm](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/charms-02-23-2017). Recently, we have been studying [the relationship between extrinsic value and theta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/extrinsic-value-theta-02-09-2017) for options of varying [degrees of moneyness](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/moneyness-07-07-2016). During that time, we have learned that deep OTM options tend to converge on a zero probability of being ITM more quickly than their expiration might suggest. The mathematical basis for this can be entirely attributed to charm, or an option’s “delta decay”. So today, Frank joins the set to continue this discussion with some more details and numerical examples. In the process, Frank and Jim stumble into a “charmhack”.

Market Measures - March 2, 2017 - The Market's Daily Moves in 2017
episodes.summary:
Today's Market Measures switches gears and looks at the market in a new light. The analysis focuses on January and February 2017 as they compare to the last 60 years in the market. 

###The Study

* S&P 500 Index (SPX) 
* 1950 - Present
* Analyzed Daily % changes (close to close)  
* Subdivided and averaged positive days and negative days
* Compared the average magnitude of negative days as a % of average positive magnitude.

###Results

There has been a clear drop in the magnitude of daily moves over the last few years, with January and February of 2017 seeing extremely small moves. 

Next, the team looked at magnitude of negative days relative to positive days. They found that 2017 so far has seen negative days far out paced by the magnitude of positive days. The only year where January and February matched this year was 1987. 

This doesn't mean the team expects a huge market sell off, just a reversion to higher market volatility. Get Tom and Tony's take! Check out the segment!

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - March 1, 2017 - Core Option Position: Managing a Loser
episodes.summary: When we have a core position, even if we are right in our hypothesis, [we will have some decisions to make](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/managing-a-winner-core-position-short-premium-10-31-2016). But, if we are wrong directionally, we will have a loser on our hands – plain and simple. If we find ourselves in this position [using deep, ITM options as our core position](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/core-positions-with-options-02-22-2017), then what adjustments and management techniques should we consider? Mike, from Everyday Trader joins us today to continue this discussion, and we see that it basically boils down to understanding [delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/an-intuitive-understanding-of-delta-03-03-2016), [extrinsic value](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/deconstructing-option-prices-03-01-2016), and debit paid.

Market Measures - March 1, 2017 - Iron Condors: How Long to 50%?
episodes.summary:
We have often talked about the defined-risk nature of the short [iron condor](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/iron-condor) and the potential reward that the strategy presents, which we often think of as 50% of the credit received. Today, we are comparing three variations of the short iron condor in SPY, but we are not looking at average profitability. Instead, Pete, Tony, and James talk about how long it has historically taken these three iron condors to get to that [50% management marker](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners) when they were profitable. ###The Study * 2010 to present
* S&P 500 ETF (SPY)
* 45 DTE options
* Sold $5 wide iron Condors with short options: 40 deltas, 30 deltas, 20 [deltas](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta)
* All trades managed at 50% of max profit
###The Results We found that, while the more aggressive iron condor (40 delta) exhibited the largest credit and potential reward at the 50% management marker, the least aggressive iron condor (20 delta) got to 50% profits the fastest.

episodes.title: Strategies for IRA - March 1, 2017 - Covered Calls with Various Durations
episodes.summary:
A [covered call](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/covered-call) can be an effective method to reduce cost basis when holding a long equity. We can also “ladder” the calls with various [strikes](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strike-price) and [expiration](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/expiration) cycles when we have more than one hundred shares of an underlying. Today, our Research Team aimed to analyze the effectiveness of laddering covered calls. Using 300 Long shares, we compared:
* selling three of the SPY 30 [delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) "traditional" covered calls with 45 DTE
* selling three SPY 30 delta laddered covered calls with 45 DTE, 75 DTE and 105 DTE Watch this segment of “Strategies for Your IRA” with Tom and Tony for the takeaways and the pros and cons of a laddered covered call.

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 28, 2017 - Credit Spreads
episodes.summary: Yesterday, [we covered debit spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/debit-spreads-02-27-2017). So today, we continue that discussion and bring the conversation full circle by examining credit spreads. At the core, when you choose a [vertical spread](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/vertical-credit-spreads-02-16-2016), you naturally must decide between buying the spread (debit) or selling the spread (credit). While these two strategies share the same characteristics and attributes, the subtle difference of selling with a credit spread creates a [far more desirable situation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/the-marshmallow-challenge-05-25-2016). James from the research desk joins the discussion to show some innovative ways to use credit spreads to simulate various positions.

Market Measures - February 28, 2017 - Long Premium in Low IV
episodes.summary:
Research has shown the benefits of selling option premium when [implied volatility is high](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility) relative to itself.

However, is this also true during periods of low IV? Does a long premium strategy perform well during these times?

In this Segment, Beef joins Pete and Tony to discuss the latest research the team came up with to determine if getting long premium is a viable strategy. Through an extensive back test, the benefit of the doubt is given to this strategy that we (as tastytraders) tend to avoid.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 28, 2017 - 4 Ways to Diversify a Portfolio
episodes.summary:
When we are keeping primarily short premium positions in our portfolio, it is important to us to ensure that our portfolio is diversified. Over the years, we at tastytrade have developed various paths that can lead to a diversified portfolio, and today Pete, Tony, and Frank review some of those diversification tools.

###Diversify by Underlying
Traders can use the [correlation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/correlation) between two stocks to see whether those two potential underlyings have historically moved together or had no real relationship.

###Diversify by Strategy
Strategies on the same underlying exhibit correlations as well, and we have used these relationships to diversify positions on an underlying that we tend to play often, like SPY and TLT.

###Diversify by Implied Volatility
We have recently been checking the correlation between stocks’ [implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility) indices to the end of diversifying the [short vegas](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vega) in our portfolio.

###Diversify by VIX
Finally, we have found that short premium trades on SPY, like short [strangles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strangle) and [straddles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle), have been much less correlated to movement in the VIX than short [call spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread) in VIX. This is because our short SPY premium trades are paid much more often via [theta decay](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/theta) and lack of price movement than via VIX movement.

tasty BITES - February 28, 2017 - Downsizing a Collar
episodes.summary:
Tom's out of town,so Pete and Bat are running the show. For this tastyBites piece, they invite James in to walk them through the segment. 

The three discuss collars, an industry standard strategy not often a topic of discussion on tastytrade. 

Collars are capital intensive in that they require being long stock as well as having an option position. A collar also includes buying a protective put-- another strategy rarely employed at tastytrade. 

James walks through the concept of a call spread replicating the collar. This position requires far less buying power and is a possible alternative for small accounts!

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 27, 2017 - Debit Spreads
episodes.summary: As a [beginner trader](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/true-beginner-part-1-why-even-invest-06-21-2016), the debit spread can be an excellent strategy to get into the market and implement some directional bias. It is a [defined-risk strategy](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/defined-risk-position-sizing-12-27-2016) that still focuses on cost basis reduction at its core. A great starting point for your strike selection on a debit spread is right around the at-the-money (ATM) strike, where your long option is slightly in-the-money (ITM), and your short option is slightly out-of-the-money (OTM). As Kai and I lay out during the segment, this guideline can be adjusted to fit the trader’s specific objectives on the trade.

episodes.title: Futures Now - February 27, 2017
Futures Measures - February 27, 2017 - Dow Futures: Adding ETF Theta
episodes.summary:
/YM is currently trading over 20,000 creating an interesting price extreme opportunity. Rather than making outright directional plays, Pete and Katie present the idea of adding in a theta component with the use of DIA, the Dow ETF. 

The duo breaks down the stock equivalent of /YM to DIA and then weighs the advantages and disadvantages of incorporating a single [Iron Condor](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/iron-condor) with a short Dow future, versus utilizing the "[double double](http://ontt.tv/2k2VRhL)," which is an Iron Condor with an uneven number of contracts on one side.

Find out how these strategies compare in terms of Maximum Profit/Loss, Buying Power Requirement and breakeven prices. Plus, discover how this idea can be incorporated into other products experiencing certain volatility skew or price extreme.

episodes.title: Know Your Options - February 27, 2017 - 30 DTE vs 60 DTE & 30 Delta vs 16 Delta
episodes.summary:
Liz and Jenny invite James in, as they do every Monday at 10:45, to discuss his favorite research segments from the previous week. 

Today, James covers two very different segments:

###Segment 1 

The first study looks at the times of the month where we can't target 45 DTE for short premium trades. The results point more favorably to 30 DTE, however the case can also be made for 60 DTE if traders already have a lot expiring in the front month cycle. 

###Segment 2 

This segment looks at 30 delta strangles compared to 16 delta strangles. Ultimately, 30 delta strangles are a low probability of profit trade. However, these trades historically have a high success rate. This is due to the breakevens and the nature of actual moves being lower than expected.

Market Measures - February 27, 2017 - GLD: Double Double Iron Condors
episodes.summary:
In today's segment, the guys discuss a new study on the "Double Double" Strategy. The gold market is known to see shifting [skew](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/volatility-skew), where calls can be more expensive than puts and vice-versa.

Because of this, can we sell multiple call spreads to a wide put spread or multiple put spreads to wide call spreads depending on the market environment?

###Study

* Gold ETF (GLD)
* June 2008 - Present
* 45 DTE
* Short 30 [Delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) Strangle (Long 5 Delta Wings)
* Compared:
* 1 wide put spread, 1 wide call spread
* Double Doubles (depending on skew) 
* 1 wide put spread, multiple call spreads -OR- 1 wide call spread, multiple put spreads
as many as possible without increasing total BPR

###Results

The results from the standard trade compared to executing "Double Double" trades where possible were extremely similar. 

A closer look demonstrates that the opportunity to execute multiple [call or put spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread) is extremely rare in GLD. This means that the skew does not exhibit an extreme in either direction very often.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 27, 2017 - Trades Made Reasonable By Low Commissions
episodes.summary:
Tom starts of the segment by presenting some trades that he has opened this morning in stocks that are so small that he would not have been able to put the trades on with a less flexible fee structure. The reason why we truly appreciate low fees for initiating and managing options positions lies within the flexibility that these competitive commission rates afford us. This means that we can play options strategies in smaller stocks and options strategies with more legs with greater ease.

Tom talks through a couple potential current trading opportunities in the market that pertain to smaller fees allowing for:

* Managing trades early
* Initiating multi-legged trades
* Initiating smaller profit potential trades

Example trades include the following underlyings: IWM, EEM, SPY, and TSLA.

episodes.title: Good Trade Bad Trade - February 24, 2017
Market Measures - February 24, 2017 - Skew and Managing Winners
episodes.summary:
Skew in index ETFs makes the short [Strangle](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strangle) wider on the Put leg and narrower on the Call leg. This adds higher risks on the Call side than the Put side. We have known that [managing winners](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners) helps improve the performance by reducing the same risk that holding-to-[expiration](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/expiration) is fully exposed to. Today, our Research Team analyzed how the Skew impacts the performance when winners are managed. In particular, our team compared:
* The stock price being higher than entry price
* The stock price being lower than entry price
* The stock price being the same as entry price
Ultimately, when looking at skewed Strangles in bullishly biased ETFs, the Put option more greatly influenced [premium decay](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/theta) and increased the speed at which the strategy was a 50% winner. For detailed analysis, watch the segment and see what Tom and Tony have to say about the relationship between Skew and Managing Winners.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 24, 2017 - Fear of Volatility Expansion
episodes.summary:
Selling premium in [high IV](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility) is ideal because the trader will likely benefit from a volatility contraction. But when selling low IV,  there is a risk of IV expansion [(short Vega)](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vega).

How serious has this risk been over time?

To put context around volatility expansion risk, we examined the frequency and magnitude of expansions. Recorded VIX on Day 1 and on Day 45, and computed the difference. This was done every trading day since 1990.

In very low IV, 75% of 45 day periods saw a VIX change of less than 2.5 points. So, it was fairly rare to see a significant change at the end of the period. More detailed results are shown in the segment.

In the end, trade P/L often comes from [time decay (Theta)](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/theta) and [price movement (Delta)](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) more than it does volatility, so this fear of volatility expansion shouldn’t necessarily deter you from trading.

While selling premium in [low IVR](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility) has been profitable, it’s reasonable to mitigate IV expansion by staying small and keeping short delta.

As the mantra goes, trade small and trade often, even in low IVR.

Closing the Gap - Futures Edition - February 24, 2017 - Currency Carry Trade & Equities
episodes.summary:
A common "carry" trade in the currency world is borrowing Yen (/6J) at zero interest rates, converting the money into dollars and then investing into S&P 500. With its high positive correlation to S&P, this trade also tends to be a risk gauge for global investment. Today, tastytrade takes it one step further by explaining the Yen-Kiwi trade and its role in assessing market risk. Watch this segment to understand the proper ratio of the /6J-/6N spread and discover how its divergence from S&P can indicate directional market momentum. ###YEN Contract Specs
* Symbol: /6J
* Contract Size: 12,500,000 YEN
* Delta: 12500000
* Minimum Tick: $0.0000005
* Tick Value: $6.25
* Expiration: March, June, September, December
###NEW ZEALAND $ Contract Specs
* Symbol: /6N
* Contract Size: 100,000 NZD
* Delta: 1000000
* Minimum Tick: $0.0001
* Tick Value: $10
* Expiration: March, June, September, December

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 23, 2017 - Charms
episodes.summary: The last couple weeks, we’ve been stuck on the same conversation with our advanced segments: the relationship between [extrinsic value](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/time-value-awareness-06-27-2016) and [theta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/portfolio-theta-part-one-10-26-2016). At first, we simply made an observation that their relationship between each other was [nonlinear in nature](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/convexity-and-concavity-01-05-2017). The reasoning behind this [eluded us at first](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/extrinsic-value-theta-02-09-2017), but we began to [intuitively piece it together](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/extrinsic-value-theta-the-answer-02-16-2017). Today, thanks to the outstanding work of Frank from the research desk, we’re able to support this understanding with the [mathematical foundation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/quantitative-finance-05-11-2016) that was absent – until now.

1.  Measure the relative performance of a trade after we exit the position. 

2. Measure the relative efficiency of how our capital will be used in a trade. 

3. Gauge whether we’re at an acceptable point of exit for a trade.

episodes.title: Good Trade Bad Trade - February 23, 2017
Market Measures - February 23, 2017 - Comparing 30 Delta Breakevens to 16 Delta Strikes
episodes.summary:
tasytrade strangle studies often focus on either on 16 delta, or more recently, 30 delta strangles.

The 30 [delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) strikes have a much lower [probability of profit](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/probability-of-profit) than 16 delta strangles, yet have historically been profitable in our studies. Why is this?

###The Study

* S&P 500 ETF (SPY)
* 2005 - Present 
* 45 DTE 
* Compared 
* Short [1 SD](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/standard-deviation) strangles (16 delta call and put)
* Short ½ SD strangles (30 delta call and put)
* Managed at 50% where possible

One main point is the success rates on the 30 delta strangles compared to the probability of profit. 

The other focus of the data was on the breakeven points of the 30 delta strangles, compared to the strikes of the 16 delta strangles.  

###The Results

The 30 delta strangle has an actual success rate above the expected success rate of the 16 delta strangle. This even holds true with no [management](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners). 

It's fair to assume that this is due to the extra premium collected-- pushing out the breakeven on the 30 delta strangle.

On average the 30 delta strangle "breakeven range" is 89% of the 16 delta strike range. This, combined with the markets implied moves being overstated leads to a high win rate for the 30 delta strangles.

episodes.title: The Skinny On Options Data Science - February 23, 2017 - Machine Learning Trump's Tweets
episodes.summary:
In today's Skinny on Options Data Science, Dr. Data (Michael Rechenthin, PhD) explained how data science can be used to analyze large quantities of data.  As an example, he examined over 30,500 of Donald Trump's tweets to better understand how modern data science techniques can be used to find the most popular themes and tone of tweets for each year.  As Dr. Data said, "the computing power and techniques that we now have allows us to do things that would have been impossible just a few years ago.


He started out with a table of some of the most popular words by year and then quickly transitioned to providing a "tone score" to each of the tweets.  

An example of a positive tweet was:
> *Gov. John Kasich of the GREAT, GREAT, GREAT state of Ohio called to congratulate me on the win.  The people of Ohio were incredible!*

And an example of a negative tweet was:
> *Gen. John Allen, who I never met by the way spoke against me last night, failed badly in his fight against ISIS. His record = BAD    #NeverHillary*

All of this was done automatically with the use of data science / machine learning algorithms.  To see more, please watch the show!

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 22, 2017 - Core Positions with Options
episodes.summary: Often times as traders, we like to establish a core position. This is nothing more than [some directional bias](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/directional-trades-building-an-assumption-01-28-2016), bullish or bearish, that we want to be the focal point of our portfolio. Usually, we will use stock or futures to accomplish this, as these instruments offer us the static deltas that we want. But, if you’re in a situation where you don’t want to trade stock or you can’t trade futures, then you can replicate this same idea with options only. Mike, from Everyday Trader, joins the set today to show us exactly how that can be done.

episodes.title: Talkin' With Tom and Tony - February 22, 2017

Market Measures - February 22, 2017 - Strategy Correlation to Implied Volatility
episodes.summary:
Here at tastytrade, we like to use [correlation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/correlation) to diversify our portfolios among underlyings, strategies, and [implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility) of underlyings. Today, Tom and Tony take a look at using correlation in order to see how two different trades’ Profit and Losses relate to the VIX level when the trade is initiated.

###The Study

* 2010 to present
* S&P 500 ETF (SPY) and S&P 500 Volatility Index (VIX)
* 45 DTE
* Compared short premium and short VIX trade correlation to VIX level

###The Results

We found that [short premium trades](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strangle) are not as correlated to the VIX level on entry as we might have thought. This is most likely due to our positive decay, or [long theta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/theta), producing profits in all environments. The short VIX strategy was much more highly correlated to the VIX level, as short VIX [call spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread) have been historically more profitable when we are selling a high VIX.

Check out the segment above for more detailed results.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 22, 2017 - Why We Sell VIX In All Environments
episodes.summary:
The purpose of this segment is to show that [implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility) is “overstated in all environments,” hence our primary play being short IV and hoping for it to stay near its mean in the long term. After defining the concept of "IV clustering," Tom and Tony move on to looking at VIX highs and lows and how short VIX strategies worked historically in both environments.

Surprisingly, there have been very few [occurrences](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/number-of-occurrences) of VIX over 30 since 2004. Therefore, we (as tastytraders) try to be as aggressive as possible in getting short VIX when we do see these high levels. 

Finally, Tom and Tony talk through how low VIX occurrences tend to be followed by more low VIX levels. Because of this, short VIX positions have also tended to be consistently profitable when the VIX is on the lower side. Check out the segment above to see how the historical results of short VIX call spreads have played out.

WDIS: Options 101 - February 21, 2017 - Here Comes Volatility!
episodes.summary:
###SYLLABUS
[Click here to download the WDIS: Options 101 Syllabus](https://s3.amazonaws.com/tastytradepublicmedia/website/cms/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf/original/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf)

Back from a holiday weekend, Dr. Jim does not take it easy on today's lesson for Brittany. In doing so, she quickly learns that she is finally able to take a term off the shelf that has been there for quite some time - volatility (which is one of the six factors impacting an option's price). To Brittany, volatility means unpredictable, unstable, or chaotic. Then, she learns that as [option prices rise, volatility rises, and if option prices fall, volatility falls](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/volatility-contraction-expansion-08-01-2016). In other words, she quickly notices that these two variables are [positively correlated](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/wdis-options-101/episodes/the-intuition-of-correlation-02-09-2017) with each other. One of her key takeaways from the day was that with volatility, we can begin to know [the fluctuations that we could expect in a given stock](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/time-weighted-ranges-02-01-2017).

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 21, 2017 - The Poor Man’s Version: Covered Calls & Covered Puts
episodes.summary: We recently went over covered calls and covered puts, in their standard versions. But today, we look to extend that discussion by examining the poor man’s version of each of one of these strategies: [The Poor Man’s Covered Call](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/strategy-session-poor-mans-covered-call-06-14-2016) and [The Poor Man’s Covered Put](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/strategy-session-poor-mans-covered-put-06-16-2016). What we learn is that these strategies are essentially no different from their more basic counterparts, with the stock components simply being simulated with long options. To help us with these strategies, James from the research team joins us. Not only does he help give us a clearer context around how these strategies set up, but he also reminds us how “hard-to-borrow” stocks fit into this conversation.

episodes.title: Know Your Options - February 21, 2017 - Straddle Premium & Put Ratio Spreads
episodes.summary:
James joins Liz and Jenny for another Know Your Options segment to discuss two recent studies. 

### Study 1 
First James explains a study looking at straddle premium relative to expected moves. The study goes on to examine how short straddles compare to being long or short stock. 

### Study 2
This study looked at put ratio spreads in SPY. The team worked with Tom Sosnoff to see how he set up put ratios. The result was this study looking at being long the 50 delta put and short 2x 33 delta puts. 

The study goes on to examine the results in all environments as well as occurrences with IVR above 35.

Market Measures - February 21, 2017 - In Between Expirations: 30 or 60 DTE?
episodes.summary:
We know from our research that 45 days to [expiration](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/expiration) is the optimal time frame to capture the highest amount of [theta decay](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/theta). However, what do we do when 45 days is not an available option? 

In this segment, Tom and Tony dive into a study comparing the 30-day time frame to the 60-day time frame, in an attempt to determine if one is preferred over the other.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 21, 2017 - Commissions Impact - Strangle
episodes.summary:
Commissions are one of the more important considerations in investing. We wanted to examine the cost structure of two brokerage firms. A study was conducted in SPY from 2005 to present. Using options closest to 45 days to expiration (DTE), we sold 1 [standard deviation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/standard-deviation) [Strangles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strangle). We then analyzed two scenarios:
1. Average performance of all [occurrences](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/number-of-occurrences) 2. Cumulative performance of selling one contract Watch this segment of Options Jive with Tom and Tony for the valuable analysis and the detailed study results on the impact of commissions on trading strategies.

episodes.title: Good Trade Bad Trade - February 17, 2017
Market Measures - February 17, 2017 - Straddle Premiums & Expected Moves
episodes.summary:
When selling [Straddles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle), we collect the maximum premium for that specific option chain. Is that premium enough to cover the actual move netting a positive result? Our Research Team ran a study to find out! ###The Study
* S&P 500 (SPY) * 2005 - Present * Short ATM Straddles (50 [Delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) Call, 50 Delta Put) * [Managed](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners) at 25% of max profit * Also analyzed the actual underlying movement ###The Results Actual moves in the underlying, on average, amount to 63% of the expected move. The Straddle credit, on average, covers 73% of the expected move. Historically, the Straddle results saw more consistent profits than long or short stock.

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 17, 2017
Closing the Gap - Futures Edition - February 17, 2017 - Oil vs. Gold: Relative Value Dynamics
episodes.summary:
The number of barrels of Crude (/CL) required to purchase one ounce of Gold (/GC) is known as the Oil-Gold Ratio. Given the price activity in Crude Oil over the past years (while Gold has held steady), the ratio has experienced large swings. Recently, however, the ratio has seen a significant decline. In hopes of a reversion, Pete, Tom and Tony present a pairs trade in these two commodities which would capitalize on more barrels of Oil required to purchase an oz. of Gold. The [notional value](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/notional-value) of /GC is currently more than twice the size of Crude Oil. However, the [implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility) in Crude is double that of Gold. In order to properly set up this pair, Pete breaks down the calculation: Ratio = (Crude Notional/Gold Notional) x IV Differential Percentage ###GOLD Contract Specs
* Symbol: /GC
* Contract Size:100 TROY OZ
* Delta: 100
* Minimum Tick: $0.10
* Tick Value: $10.00
* Expiration: February, April, June, August, October December
###CRUDE OIL Contract Specs
* Symbol: /CL
* Contract Size: 1000 BARRELS
* Delta: 1000
* Minimum Tick: $0.10
* Tick Value: $10.00
* Expiration: MONTHLY
Tune in for the full discussion as well as how Pete, Tom and Tony reasonably expect to manage this spread.

episodes.title: WDIS: Options 101 - February 16, 2017 - Buying Power Reduction
episodes.summary:
###SYLLABUS
[Click here to download the WDIS: Options 101 Syllabus](https://s3.amazonaws.com/tastytradepublicmedia/website/cms/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf/original/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf)

Today, Dr. Jim provides an overview of a very simple concept, "buying power reduction", which is how much capital the brokerage firm sets aside as collateral for a given trade. Brittany learned that the buying power reduction on defined risk trades is easy to determine, as it is directly tied to the maximum loss on the position. However, for undefined risk trades, [it is a little trickier](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/undefined-risk-position-sizing-12-29-2016). The key takeaway from today to build on Brittany's understanding was to better understand the 'trade small' portion of the ['trade small, trade often'](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/the-central-limit-theorem-09-30-2016) mantra, and for her to think about buying power reduction in regards to position sizes relative to her account size.

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 16, 2017 - Extrinsic Value & Theta: The Answer?
episodes.summary: Just last week, [we began a journey from out-of-the-money to at-the-money](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/extrinsic-value-theta-02-09-2017), where we wanted to take a closer look at what happens to both extrinsic value and theta. Not surprisingly, we see both of these metrics rising, and the rationale behind why is largely one of [risk and return](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/rethinking-risk-return-03-29-2016). However, we also learn that their relative relationship to each other is [concave in nature](https://tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/concavity-in-trading-01-19-2017) (not to be confused with a [convex relationship](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/convexity-in-trading-01-12-2017)). At first, we weren’t sure why this was the case, but today, we’re able to piece together at least a partial explanation.

Market Measures - February 16, 2017 - Put Ratio Backtest
episodes.summary:
A recent [Best Practices](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/best-practices/episodes/how-to-set-up-ratio-spreads-02-13-2017) segment showed how we like to set up [ratio spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/ratio-spread) when we are either trying to create a certain amount of [long or short deltas](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) or trying to profit from the underlying pinning a [certain strike](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strike-price). Today, we are looking specifically at the put ratio and how it has performed as a strategy in all environments versus times of [high IV Rank](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility).

##The Study

* 2005 to present
* S&P 500 ETF (SPY)
* 45 DTE
* Bought one 50 delta put & sold two 33 puts

Tom predicted that this strategy should have performed well in the mostly bull market that we have seen since 2005. What is interesting, though, is how this strategy worked in high IVR and what proportion of [trades expired](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/expiration) in the larger profit zone as opposed to profit zone where only the net credit was received.

##The Results

Of course, Tom is right again! Put ratio spreads in SPY have been profitable since 2005, with greater profits seen in high IV Rank environments. Check the segment above for more details on this strategy for creating long deltas.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 16, 2017 - Being Realistic About Profitability
episodes.summary:
A popular question asked from the Research Team is "How do I make $XXX per month?"  While there are no guarantees in trading, this segment helps a trader run through the math in order to get a ballpark estimate.

There are several factors to consider:

1. Amount of [extrinsic](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/option-value)
2. Profit targets
3. Strategy [success rate](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/probability-of-profit)
4. Drawdowns, magnitude, and [frequency](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/number-of-occurrences)

### 1) Amount of Extrinsic
The first thing to consider is the amount of extrinsic value needed.  If we wanted to make $100 a month, we will need at least $100 in premium.


### 2) Profit Targets
If we [manage at 50%](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners), we will need at least double the amount we want to make.

### 3) Strategy Success Rate
Depending on the success rate, we will need to take that into consideration.  If a strategy has a success rate of 90%, then we will only have success (on average) in 10 or 11 months of the year.

### 4) Drawdowns, Magnitude and Frequency
Drawdowns, magnitude, and frequency of losses should always be taken into consideration.

For more information, watch the segment.  Tom said, "Had we had this information when we began our trading careers, our results would have been very different."

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 15, 2017 - Price Discovery
episodes.summary: Price Discovery, a term that you’ve probably heard us toss around a time or two, is actually an integral part of the trading process. The [market maker always maintains a market](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/bid-ask-spreads-02-11-2016), where he is ready to be the counterparty to our trade. If we are willing to transact at his prices, we can be filled immediately on these orders. However, we could also attempt to [work the order inside of the posted quote](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/high-frequency-help-05-27-2016), and sell above the bid, buy below the ask, or anchor somewhere around the midpoint between the two. Mike (from Everyday Trader) joins us in the studio and brings with him the perfect example to illustrate the important role that [liquidity](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/liquidity-02-23-2016) plays in this process.

Futures Measures - February 15, 2017 - Rolling Futures
episodes.summary:
When futures contracts are nearing expiration, traders can either close the position, let it expire or roll it forward to a later dated expiration. Today, Pete and Katie walk through the third option. Learn how to properly time your futures rolls based on volume, how to set the roll up as a spread and how the pricing of later dated expirations will influence a trader's cost basis. Plus, discover how these "calendar" spreads will display in an account and whether positive or negative carry will prevail based on the term structure of the curve and whether your position is long or short. 

[Access the CME Rolling Spread Guide](https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/equity-index/files/EQ_spreads_guide.pdf)

episodes.title: Market Measures - February 15, 2017 - Stock Performance at 50% Winner
episodes.summary:
Historically, when we were able to manage winners at 50% of the initial max credit, where did the stock end: Up, Down, or Unchanged? There are two general observations from historical stock market performance:
1. Long-term positive drift
2. Higher probability of tail risk with greater duration Our Research Team wondered if the stock performance is consistent with these rules when [managing at 50% winners](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners). In today’s segment, Tom and Tony will explain why the stock performance helps improve the performance of managing winners.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 15, 2017 - When to Use What IV
episodes.summary:
When traders are trying to set up [expectations for future price movement](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/standard-deviation) of a stock or index, the [implied volatility (IV)](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility) of options on that underlying product is essential. However, the question persists: which IV should we be using in order to calculate the expected price range that we are seeking?

Since we like to have as many tools at our disposal as possible, e.g. underlying IV, option chain IV, [IV Rank](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility), etc., choosing the correct number when seeking expected moves can be daunting. Thankfully, Tom takes some time during the segment to show how he would use the tastyworks platform to find the IV he would use for a few different scenarios. For example, expected moves can be seem out of line around [earnings announcements](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/earnings) and other binary events, making it very important to know which IV is being used to price what duration’s move. We default to the option chain IV when looking to price an expected move. This is because we like to look at the IV of the exact time frame that we are observing. Check out the segment above to catch a small tutorial on choosing the right IV!

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 15, 2017
Strategies for IRA - February 15, 2017 - IRA Compatible
episodes.summary: Replicating margin in an IRA account is the focus in today's segment. Because [naked risk](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/naked-options) is not allowed on the Call side and must be cash-secured on the Put side, trading options in an IRA can be prohibitive. Tom and Tony walk through ways to still trade options in your account and explain how to replicate the [buying power](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/glossary) of a margin account through the purchase of wings. If you trade options in your IRA account this is a must see episode!

episodes.summary:
###SYLLABUS
[Click here to download the WDIS: Options 101 Syllabus](https://s3.amazonaws.com/tastytradepublicmedia/website/cms/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf/original/WDISOptions101Syllabus.pdf)

In today's episode, Dr. Jim preps Brittany to place her first ever [calendar spread](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/calendar-spreads-when-long-vega-backfires-11-09-2016). The two go over a few important tips to before she looks to fill the order: she never wants to pay more than the extrinsic value of the short option in the front month, she will look to [manage a winning](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/managing-a-winner-core-position-short-premium-10-31-2016) calendar spread more aggressively at 20%-25% of what she paid for it, and whenever she buys something, she always looks to sell something against it (i.e. [cost basis reduction](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/review-session-beginner-03-31-2016)). Dr. Jim wraps up the show by briefly discussing how to combine diversification with correlation.

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 14, 2017 - The Covered Put
episodes.summary: Yesterday, we explored [one of the most basic ways to play the market to the upside](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/the-covered-call-02-13-2017). Today, we bring that conversation full circle (in the words of Shakespeare), by reminding ourselves of one of the simplest ways to play the market to the downside – the Covered Put (which can also be done in a [poor man's version](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/from-theory-to-practice-06-16-2016)). This strategy is nothing more than a directional play lower, [to protect us against higher volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/the-inverse-relationship-volatility-and-market-prices-part-deux-10-12-2016), with some short premium coming in against that bearish assumption. James, from the research team, joins the discussion to talk through some of the interesting nuances that we see with FB trading at all-time highs.

Market Measures - February 14, 2017 - Russell 2000: 50 Delta Calendar Spreads
episodes.summary:
Index calendars have been a running theme for Market Measures over the past 6 months. Today, the team takes a different approach, looking at the 50 [delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) (at-the-money) call and put [calendars](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/calendar-spread) in RUT. Previous studies focused on the 40 delta call or put calendars with a built in, slight directional bias. 

###The Study 

* Russell 2000 Index (RUT)
* 2005 - Present
* All days with [IVR below 25](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility) 
* Constructed 50 delta put and call calendars
* Long 60 DTE Options, Short 30 DTE Options
* Compared varying [management](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners) targets

###The Results 

Ultimately, the call calendars were a scratch to a small loss historically. The put calendars, on the other hand, had more favorable results. 

Check out Tom and Tony's discussion for their full insight and breakdown of the results.

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 14, 2017
tasty BITES - February 14, 2017 - Getting Small with Sector ETFs
episodes.summary:
Tom begins the segment with a conversation about the importance of young traders getting their [feet wet in the options world](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/number-of-occurrences) even if they have a smaller account. Moving on to the research, the guys show how small-account traders can gain short premium exposure in equities without sacrificing multiple thousands of dollars in buying power requirement (BPR), which is usually the case in the liquid underlyings like SPY and IWM that we like to trade.

Sector ETFs like XLK and XRT, technology and retail stocks, allow for traders with smaller accounts to get in the game without putting up a considerable portion of their account in BPR. This is because most of these ETFs have smaller prices, and thus have smaller margin requirements. The sector ETFs that Tom presents here combine both great liquidity and [diversification](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/correlation) so that traders can pick and choose where they think short premium opportunity might lie, dependent on which has the highest [IV Rank](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility).

Finally, historical results are shown for [short straddles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle) in the sector ETFs that the team has used as examples for this segment. History dictates that [implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/implied-volatility) also overstates in these sector ETFs as well as the market indices like SPY and IWM.

episodes.title: Futures Measures - February 13, 2017 - Futures Options: Strike Selection
episodes.summary: When trading equity options, the [at-the-money](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strike-price) strike is always at the same place: the current price of the underlying. In futures options, however, the at-the-money option depends on the price of the future's contract, which can vary by expiration date. Pete and Katie use /CL as an example to explain how to properly set up strikes in options on futures. Learn how volume in the outrights and liquidity in the options can help traders reduce slippage and optimize their [trade entry](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/order-entry-checklist).

episodes.title: Know Your Options - February 13, 2017 - Intraday Management Potential & BPR Efficient Iron Condors
episodes.summary:
Jenny's out today but that doesn't mean "Know Your Options: Best of the Research Team" is cancelled! 

James still joins Liz to recap two of the best studies from last week.

The [first study](http://ontt.tv/2jTXo9B) looks at occurrences of short strangles that hit 45% of max profit but were a loss at expiration. Most tastytrade studies are constructed with end of day data, meaning intraday management opportunities are not captured in the results. 
The conclusion from this study was that in some cases, actual results for management studies could be better than the data infers. 

The [second study](http://ontt.tv/2k2VRhL) analyzes Tom's new favorite trade, the Double Double. This trade is constructed from an iron condor where the put spread is at least double the width of the call spread. The results suggested that historically it may have been worth it to add an extra call spread where possible.

episodes.title: Know Your Options - February 13, 2017 - Intraday Management Potential & BPR Efficient Iron Condors
episodes.summary:
Jenny's out today but that doesn't mean "Know Your Options: Best of the Research Team" is cancelled! 

James still joins Liz to recap two of the best studies from last week.

The [first study](http://ontt.tv/2jTXo9B) looks at occurrences of short strangles that hit 45% of max profit but were a loss at expiration. Most tastytrade studies are constructed with end of day data, meaning intraday management opportunities are not captured in the results. 
The conclusion from this study was that in some cases, actual results for management studies could be better than the data infers. 

The [second study](http://ontt.tv/2k2VRhL) analyzes Tom's new favorite trade, the Double Double. This trade is constructed from an iron condor where the put spread is at least double the width of the call spread. The results suggested that historically it may have been worth it to add an extra call spread where possible. 

Watch the video for the full discussion and takeaways!

episodes.title: Good Trade Bad Trade - February 13, 2017
Market Measures - February 13, 2017 - What's Eating Your Profits?
episodes.summary:
We pride ourselves on our ability to be flexible in trades when [initiating](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/order-entry-checklist) and [managing](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners) our positions, and a lower fee structure for trading options lends to this idea greatly. Tom and Tony compare a couple of commissions schedules relative to a historically profitable trade – the [iron condor](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/iron-condor) – to see how the historical profits would have changed given higher commissions per trade.

###The Results
The larger exemplary commissions schedule would have eaten more than 60% of the iron condor’s profit on a trade-by-trade basis. From 2005 to present, profits would have been more than double for the trader using the smaller commissions schedule versus the larger example.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 13, 2017 - Trading Calendars and Diagonals
episodes.summary:
Calendars and Diagonals are [low implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility) strategies -- the type of environment that we are currently in. More specifically:
* [Calendar Spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/calendar-spread) look to sell one option and buy another with the same strike and type with the only difference being the expiration cycle.
* [Diagonals](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/diagonal-spread) are very similar to calendars, with the difference being they have directional bias with an "embedded" vertical spread. Both strategies are long [vega](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vega). This means that increases in implied volatility have a positive impact on the profitability of the strategy. For more information, watch the segment and see what Tom and Tony have to say about the strategies.

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 13, 2017
Best Practices - February 13, 2017 - How To Set Up Ratio Spreads
episodes.summary:
Today, Tom and Tony cover one of our more intricate strategies – [ratio spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/ratio-spread). Ratio spreads are done for a credit so that there is no direction to one side, and there is a larger profit potential to the other side. This is where the intricacies of this strategy come in; that is, ratio spreads can profit in both directions. With a 2-by-1 ratio spread, we would be buying one options and then selling 2 of the same options further out-the-money for a net credit. This creates a synthetic short option where we would make money if the underlying goes infinitely in one direction (up for put ratios and down for call ratios) and make potentially more if the underlying goes against us slightly pinning our short [strike](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strike-price).

Tom talks through the profitability zones of a put ratio as an example, and he presents the probabilities of these different zones. He poses ratios as a higher [probability of profit (POP)](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/probability-of-profit) strategy that can be used by beginning traders who are trying to become comfortable with [naked options](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/naked-options). Check out the segment above for more details on this strategy.

episodes.title: Good Trade Bad Trade - February 10, 2017
Market Measures - February 10, 2017 - Converting to /ES: Scaling Up SPY
episodes.summary:
Pete and Tony are at the helm today, so they invite James in to discuss S&P 500 Futures (/ES) options as a stepping stone for traders looking to size up positions in the S&P 500 ETF (SPY). 

James explains the [notional](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/notional-value) difference between /ES and SPY and that /ES options results can theoretically be extrapolated from SPY results. We would expect the historical success rate to be very similar, while P/L would likely be 5x the SPY values. This is simply a function of the 5x notional difference between /ES and SPY 

The guys then discuss the potential benefits of /ES compared to SPY, these include:

* Lower initial buying power 
* Higher potential return on capital
* Lower possibility of early [assignment](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/assignment) as futures do not have a dividend 

Check out the video to hear the full discussion!

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 10, 2017
Closing the Gap - Futures Edition - February 10, 2017 - Getting Small with Treasury Spreads
episodes.summary:
The US Treasury market exhibits some of the greatest liquidity of any futures markets, which provides us with a great market for scalping potential. Today Pete, Tony, and Frank talk through a scalping strategy that plays on the relationship between two parts of the curve rather than just trading a single outright. The idea here is to take the directional aspect of trading futures outrights out of the equation in order to play the steepening and flattening of the yield curve. This allows traders to be in the trade longer as the historic daily range of these spreads is usually tighter than that of the singular outrights. The gang places the spotlight on the belly of the curve – looking at the FIT spread comprising of the Five-Year Treasury Note (/ZF) and the Ten-Year Treasury Note (/ZF). Frank walks through some of the historical data on this futures spread and the two potential ways to trade it. ###5-Year Treasury Note Contract Specs
* Symbol: /ZF
* Multiplier: $1000
* Minimum Tick: $7.8125
* Tick Value: $31.25
* Expiration: QUARTERLY
###10-Year Treasury Note Contract Specs
* Symbol: /ZN
* Multiplier: $1000
* Minimum Tick: $15.625
* Tick Value: $31.25
* Expiration: QUARTERLY

episodes.title: From Theory To Practice - February 9, 2017 - Extrinsic Value & Theta
episodes.summary: If we stop and think about our entire operation as tastytraders, we realize that it largely depends on two pieces: [extrinsic value](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/time-value-awareness-06-27-2016) and [theta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/undercover-theta-04-06-2016). Today, we take a closer look at the how both of these behave as we move from OTM options to ATM options. Not surprisingly, they both increase, which makes sense because [we are taking on more risk](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/real-risk-05-16-2016). However, as we learn today when Frank joins us in the studio, the relative rates of increase illustrate another prime example of [concavity](https://tastytrade.com/tt/shows/from-theory-to-practice/episodes/concavity-in-trading-01-19-2017).

Market Measures - February 9, 2017 - Diversifying Bond Short Premium
episodes.summary:
Today we add to the conversation concerning [diversifying](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/correlation) short premium trades, which was started last week with [diversifying equity short premium](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/market-measures/episodes/diversifying-equity-short-premium-02-03-2017). Tom begins the conversation by talking about his favorite markets to sell premium on consistently, and how he trades them simultaneously hoping that some markets pick up the slack when other markets are hurting his positions. The objective behind showing all these relationships is to display the benefits of keeping a diversified portfolio when selling premium.

This study looks at how Gold (GLD) and S&P 500 (SPY) [short straddles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle) historically acted when short straddles in US Treasury Bonds (TLT) lost. This was done to show which of these underlyings displayed profitable short premium trades to help offset losing trades in TLT.

##The Results
Short straddles in SPY, historically, showed positive average P/Ls when TLT short premium trades [were losers](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/defending-positions). GLD did not respond as well. Check the above video to see the exact results of the study.

episodes.title: The Skinny On Options Data Science - February 9, 2017 - Third Most Important Thing to Consider (w/ Spreadsheet)
episodes.summary:
## Spreadsheet

To download the spreadsheet used in the video, click [here.](https://s3.amazonaws.com/tastytradepublicmedia/website/cms/SKINNY_options_analysis.xlsx/original/SKINNY_options_analysis.xlsx)

## Summary

Michael Rechenthin (Dr. Data) explains a [spreadsheet](https://s3.amazonaws.com/tastytradepublicmedia/website/cms/SKINNY_options_analysis.xlsx/original/SKINNY_options_analysis.xlsx) that can be used to compare different brokerage commission structures. Depending on your inputs, there can be as much of a 90% difference.  

The example that was used in the show showed a 84% in commissions which meant on a $100,000 account an investor could make 7.4% less and still have the same return. These relatively modest changes in commissions can mean huge differences in portfolio performance over time.

Watch the show to see Tom and Tony's take on things!

Watch the show to see Tom and Tony's take on things!

episodes.title: Futures Measures - February 8, 2017 - What Is "Span Margin?"
episodes.summary: Standardized Portfolio analysis of risk-- also known as SPAN margin-- uses a global assessment of one-day risk to determine a trader's margin per product and per position. Katie and Pete dive into SPAN margin and explain how this widely-used model is based on a series of parameters, enabling clearing firms to give traders more capital efficient portfolios They also discuss how SPAN margin changes given various "extreme" scenarios and reinforce why traders should always keep some capital on the sidelines.

Market Measures - February 8, 2017 - Wide Iron Condors: Double Double
episodes.summary:
When setting up strangle replacement trades, we often look at buying cheap wings against our [short options](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/naked-options). This is essential to reducing buying power reduction, especially in an IRA. Often when buying cheap wings, the call spread ends up being much tighter than the wide put spread. This is due to normal put skew in equities and equity ETFs. Given that the put spread is often double the width of the call spread, does it make sense to add a second [call spread](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread) for no additional capital? ###The Study The team utilized SPY options from 2005 to Present: * 45 DTE
* Short 30 [Delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) Strangle (Long 5 Delta Wings)
* Compared:
* 1 wide put spread, 1 wide call spread
* 1 wide put spread, multiple call spreads (as many as possible without increasing total BPR)
* [Managed](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners) at 50% of Max Profit (where possible)
###The Results Nearly 60% of all trades analyzed had at least 2 call spreads to the 1 put spread. Adding the second (or third) call spread did increase the risk to the upside, however, the win rate and average P/Ls also increased. Check out the video for the full results and study breakdown!

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 8, 2017 - Why Neutral Strategies Rule
episodes.summary:
The ultimate goal of investing is to find strategies that achieve both higher return and lower risk. Today’s Options Jive explore the risk to reward comparison of [neutral strategies](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) versus [directional ones](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/naked-options). An example is a [straddle](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle) - it’s comprised of selling an ATM put and an ATM call. It’s reasonable to assume that the opposing delta of the put and call would reduce the risk of the straddle.

How has this assumption played out historically?
Do neutral strategies noticeably outperform on a risk-adjusted basis?

##The Study
SPY, 2005-Present
Sold an ATM Put, ATM Call, and a Straddle, closest to 45 DTE, managed winners.
Compared average returns and [standard deviation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/standard-deviation).

##The Results
Neutral strategies performed better in all environments, having historically resulted in a lower standard deviation of returns and better average returns. View the video for more detailed results.

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 8, 2017
tasty BITES - February 8, 2017 - 3 Ways to Save on Buying Power
episodes.summary:
Those trading small accounts wishing to primarily sell premium incur the task of trying to gain as much long [theta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/theta) as possible for the buying power that they have at their disposal. In this week’s tastybites, we share a few tips on how traders of small accounts can reduce their buying power reduction (BPR) in certain trades while still gaining the exposure that they desire.

Tom and Tony talk through adding long wings to [short straddle](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/straddle) positions in order to reduce the amount of BPR that the trade requires. Though this reduces the credit received, traders still gain long theta and are exposed to less [gamma](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/gamma) risk. Next, the duo show how options can be used to replicate long or short stock so that small account traders do not have to put up as much money to gain [delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) exposure. Finally, the conversation concludes with some notes on why we sell premium primarily during high [IV Rank (IVR)](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility) environments; that is, we get a larger credit and potential return on capital (ROC) for the BPR posted for the trade.

Beta is sometimes not responsive enough (too much data used in calculations)
Beta isn’t as helpful in turmoil, since correlations become 1.

Market Measures - February 7, 2017 - Trading the Sector ETFs
episodes.summary:
Today's Market Measure is a discussion of the Sector ETFs -- it is jammed pack with useful information. Several talking points are noted in the conversation:
* Unlike the indices (SPY, DIA, IWM) there isn't a strong [correlation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/correlation) among all of the sector ETFs
* All of the sector ETFs were, on average, profitable when examining 1 [standard deviation](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/standard-deviation), 45 day until expiration strangles.
* Financials (XLF) had some of the highest average profitability, along with some of the highest average success rates.
* Consumer Staples (XLP) had some of the lowest profits, but also tends to have [lower implied volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/measuring-implied-volatility), so this is to be expected.
* Not all of the ETFs offered the same level of diversification. Some of the ETFs had more company specific risk.
Watch the segment to see Tom and Tony's take on the topic!

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 7, 2017 - Ways to Improve Probability of Profit
episodes.summary:
Ideally, traders would achieve high return on capital (ROC) and high [probability of profit](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/probability-of-profit) (POP), but it is very difficult to achieve both. Typically, higher POP comes at the expense of ROC and vice versa.

In today's Option Jive, we wanted to explore the relationship further and see what could be done to improve the POP of a trade. This includes:

1. Using [naked options](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/naked-options) instead of a risk-defined strategy
2. Financing spreads by selling additional options
3. Selling embedded [credit spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread)

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 7, 2017 - Ways to Improve Probability of Profit
episodes.summary:
Ideally, traders would achieve high return on capital (ROC) and high [probability of profit](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/probability-of-profit) (POP), but it is very difficult to achieve both. Typically, higher POP comes at the expense of ROC and vice versa.

In today's Option Jive, we wanted to explore the relationship further and see what could be done to improve the POP of a trade. This includes:

1. Using [naked options](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/naked-options) instead of a risk-defined strategy
2. Financing spreads by selling additional options
3. Selling embedded [credit spreads](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vertical-spread)

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 7, 2017
Strategies for IRA - February 7, 2017 - Simulating Straddles
episodes.summary:
In an IRA, undefined risk is not permitted. Given this, what are some ways we can replicate these non-permissible strategies? In this segment, Tom and Tony segment dive into two potential defined strategies that are similar to the [Straddle](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn), but are also IRA compatible: * A Straddle with upside protection
* A skewed [Iron Fly](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/iron-fly) With an intensive back-test, the guys examine how the two compare, and if one is more suitable over the other given risk tolerance, capital requirement and directional assumption.

Everyday Trader - February 6, 2017 - Should my "P/L Open" Be Negative?
episodes.summary:
Mike & Katie explain why more often than not, our P/L Open tab will be negative because of our trading style.

The fact that we manage our winning trades, and roll losers for duration will bring that P/L Open figure down, even though our portfolio could be in great shape.

[Optimal Management](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/shows/market-measures/episodes/optimal-management-naked-options-05-12-2015) was also discussed, which is a measurement of current P/L compared to where we expect to be based on DTE.

Tune in for a great discussion!

episodes.title: Futures Measures - February 6, 2017 - When Should You Be "Delta Neutral?"
episodes.summary: Just like with equity options, [delta neutral](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) positions in futures options eliminate the directional element from the strategy. However, it doesn't necessarily mean it will stay that way. On today's segment, Pete & Katie define delta neutrality and how our directional risk changes with movement in the underlying. Then, the duo discusses the role of [time](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/theta) and [volatility](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/vega) in delta neutral positions and how traders can use [defensive mechanics](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/defending-positions) to get their delta close to zero again if their position is tested.

episodes.title: Know Your Options - February 6, 2017 - Potential Strategies For the Current Environment
episodes.summary:
Liz and Jenny invite James in for another Monday edition of "Know Your Options: Best of the Research Team".

Today, James recaps two studies from last week that analyzed strategies that were either evergreen or usable in a low IVR environment. 

The [first study](http://ontt.tv/2jR0V4y) looked at short VIX call spreads compared to the naked short call. Ultimately this trade would be better with higher IVR due to the nature of implied volatility on the VIX. However, the trade has historically looked favorable. 

The [second study] (http://ontt.tv/2jXlBKO) analyzed buying call calendar spreads in the RUT. The team compared these to last years results looking at put calendar spreads. The team concluded that the short delta component of the slightly OTM put calendar was favorable historically.

episodes.title: Good Trade Bad Trade - February 6, 2017
Market Measures - February 6, 2017 - Management Opportunities: Is the Data Fair?
episodes.summary:
Most tastytrade studies are conducted utilizing end-of-day data, this includes any research regarding [managing winners](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/managing-winners). Is this a fair representation of actual trade management where traders look to manage throughout the day?

###The Study
The team collected data on 30 delta and 16 [delta](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/delta) strangles on SPY dating back to 2005.

After breaking down standard metrics, they isolated the [occurrences](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/number-of-occurrences) that hit at least 45% of max profit on any given day but ultimately resulted in a loss by expiration. 


###The Results
Looking at both 30 delta and 16 delta [Strangles](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strangle), the team found that 10% of losing trades reached 45% of max profit using end of day data. 

The team concluded that these trades would likely have hit 50% either on that day or the following day. The main takeaway is that staying active throughout the day will provide more management opportunity than just analyzing positions at the market open or close.

episodes.title: Options Jive - February 6, 2017 - Key Elements of Probability of Expiring ITM
episodes.summary:
As tastytraders, we have a clear concept of selling premium and managing winners based on [probabilities](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/probability-of-profit). What is lost on some though is that the probability of expiring [in-the-money](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn/strike-price) changes throughout the option's cycle. Today's segment discusses the factors involved in the calculation.  Specifically: * Stock Price
* Days to Expiration
* Implied Volatility
Through three examples we learn under which scenarios changes in the above have the greatest impact.

episodes.title: Opening Bell - February 6, 2017
Best Practices - February 6, 2017 - Volatility and Vertical Spreads
episodes.summary:
How does volatility affect our choice of vertical spread? It is important to know how the various verticals react in differing volatility environments since knowledge can help provide a slight edge. For example, both of these [strategies](https://www.tastytrade.com/tt/learn) are bearish, however they react differently to a move lower in the market.
Strategy P/L Impact After Price Decrease P/L Impact After Volatility Increase
Short Call Spread Positive Negative
Long Put Spread Positive Positive
More specifically, when we have low IV Rank we tend to choose **debit spreads** and when we have higher IV Rank we tend to choose **credit spreads.** For more information, and the reasons why the spreads react the way they do in different volatility environments (hint: skew), watch the segment!
